questions.text: Identify the following pedicle shown in the picture:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Islanded/pedicled flap Picture shows islanded/pedicled flap used from the instep to resurface a heel defect. Pedicled/islanded flaps : The axial blood supply of these flaps means that they can be swung around on a stalk or even fully ‘islanded’ so that the business end of the skin being transferred can have the pedicle buried.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Random flaps : Three sides of a rectangle, bearing no specific relationship to where the blood supply enters; the length-to-breadth ratio is no more than 1.5:1. This pattern can be lengthened by ‘delaying’ the flap, a process in which the cuts are partially made and the flap is partly lifted at a first operation; it is then replaced, thus ‘training’ the blood supply from a single border of the rectangle. In a second procedure, it is raised further and finally transferred. Option: B. Axial flaps. Much longer flaps are based on known blood vessels supplying the skin. This technique was rediscovered in the 1960s and 1970s and enables many long thin flaps to be safely moved across large distances. Option: D. Free flaps . The blood supply has been isolated, disconnected, and then reconnected using microsurgery at the new site. Composite flaps. Various tissues are transferred together, often skin with bone or muscle (osteocutaneous or myocutaneous flaps, respectively). Perforator flaps. This description refers to a whole new subgroup of axial flaps, in which tissues are isolated on small perforating vessels that run from more major blood vessels to supply the surface.

questions.text: The following formula uses colloid during the resuscitation after a burn injury:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Brooke Resuscitation Formulas: Parkland formula: Crystalloid volume:4 mL/kg per % TBSA burn Colloid volume: None Free water: None Brooke: Crystalloid volume:1.5 mL/kg per % TBSA burn Colloid volume: 0.5 mL/kg per % TBSA burn Free water: 2.0 L Galveston (pediatric) 5000 mL/m2 burned area + 1500 mL/m2 total area Colloid volume: None Free water: None Most burn units use something akin to either the Parkland or Brooke formula, which calls for the administration of varying amounts of crystalloid and colloid for the first 24 hours. The fluids are generally changed in the second 24 hours, with an increase in colloid use. These are guidelines to direct resuscitation of the amount of fluid necessary to maintain adequate perfusion. The response to fluid resuscitation should be continuously monitored, and adjustments in the rate of fluid administration should be made accordingly. The Berkow formula is used to accurately determine burn size in children not to use fluids in resuscitation.

Highyeild:

Resuscitation formulas. FORMULA CRYSTALLOID VOLUME Parkland Brooke Galveston (pediatric) 4 cc/kg/% TBSA burned 2 cc/kg/% TBSA burned 5000 cc/m² burned + 1500 cc/m² total surface area TBSA, Total body surface area.

questions.text: The most common formula used in colloid-based resuscitation is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Muir and Barclay’s formula The Lund and Browder chart is useful in assessing the area of larger burns. Colloid resuscitation: Human albumin solution (HAS) is a commonly used colloid . Plasma proteins are responsible for the inward oncotic pressure that counteracts the outward capillary hydrostatic pressure. Without proteins, plasma volumes would not be maintained as there would be edema. Proteins should be given after the first 12 hours of burn because, before this time, the massive fluid shifts cause proteins to leak out of the cells. The most common colloid-based formula is the Muir and Barclay formula: 5 × percentage body surface area burnt × weight = one portion ; periods of 4/4/4, 6/6 and 12 hrs respectively; one portion to be given in each period.

Highyeild:

The Muir and Barclay formula is widely used to calculate the necessary amount of fluid infusion during the initial 36 hours after a burn injury, making it the most prevalent colloid-based formula . A total of six portions are administered within a span of 36 hours using the following schedule: Three portions are given through hourly infusions for 12 hours (one infusion every 4 hours). Two portions are given through hourly infusions for the next 12 hours (one infusion every 6 hours). The last portion is administered through a 12-hour infusion .

Extraedge:

Muir and Barclay’s formula used fresh-frozen plasma as the primary colloid . Both fresh-frozen plasma and albumin are expensive and stored in blood banks. Excessive use of these colloids can stress the renal system.

questions.text: 50 kg female admitted in burns unit, involving her 50 % TBSA, Calculate the volume of Resuscitation fluid required in the first 24 hrs.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

5L According to ATLS manual-10th edition, the resuscitation formula for thermal burns in the first 24 hrs is by the following equation: Total % of body surface area × weight(kg) × 2 = volume (ml). Half of the volume is given in the first 8 hours and the second half is given in the subsequent 16 hours.

questions.text: Tip of nose construction after surgery for BCC is done by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bilobed flap Transposition flap : The most basic design, leaving a graftable donor site; Z-plasty : For lengthening scars or tissues; Rhomboid flap : For cheek, temple, back, and flat surface defects; Rotation flap : For convex surfaces; Advancement flap : For flexor surfaces; may need triangles excised at the base to make it work (commonly called Burow’s triangles); V-to-Y advancement: Commonly used for fingertips & extremities; Bilobed flap : For convex surfaces, especially the nose;

Highyeild:

A bilobed flap is a surgical technique that is commonly used to close wounds or defects on the skin. It involves the use of two adjacent flaps of skin, with one flap serving as the primary closure and the other flap as the secondary closure. The primary flap is designed to close the main wound or defect, while the secondary flap is used to close the donor site left by the primary flap. The secondary flap is usually smaller than the primary flap and is rotated into place to cover the donor site.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Bipedicle flap : For eyelids, rarely elsewhere. Option: C. Full thickness skin graf t: used in syndactyly release in the hand and reconstruction of facial defects following skin cancer excision. Option: D. Split skin graft: simple to harvest in large areas of skin.

Extraedge:

used to improve the appearance of scars or to address asymmetry in the skin. A bilobed flap is an effective way to achieve a natural-looking closure of a wound or defect while minimizing scarring and preserving the function and appearance of the surrounding skin.

questions.text: Not a common cause of flap failure is/are:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Flap inset with relaxation The most common causes of flap failure are: Poor anatomical knowledge when raising the flap (such that the blood supply is deficient from the start); Flap inset with too much tension ; Local sepsis or a septicaemic patient; The dressing was applied too tightly around the pedicle; Microsurgical failure in free-flap surgery (usually caused by problems with surgical technique); Tobacco smoking by the patient.

Highyeild:

Various factors can lead to flap failure. Some of the most frequent causes include: Inadequate knowledge of the anatomical structure while raising the flap, which can result in an insufficient blood supply from the outset. Overly taut flap inset, leading to the tension that impairs blood flow and tissue healing. The presence of sepsis in the surrounding tissue or the patient's bloodstream can impede the healing process. Dressing that is wrapped too tightly around the pedicle, leads to vascular compromise and flap necrosis.

Extraedge:

Complications in microsurgical procedures for free-flap surgery are typically caused by surgical technique issues. A patient's tobacco smoking habit, can negatively affect tissue oxygenation and promote clotting disorders, leading to flap failure.

questions.text: Traumatic amputated part of the finger, how to the tertiary center for reconstruction?

options.label: A
options.text: Finger washed with water, rolled, and kept in a plastic bag kept in a container

options.label: B
options.text: Finger washed with ice, kept in a separate plastic bag kept over the top of ice in a container

options.label: C
options.text: Finger washed with water, kept in a plastic bag kept over the top of dry ice in a container

options.label: D
options.text: Finger washed with water, kept in a plastic bag kept over the top of ice in a container

questions.correct_answer: D. Finger washed with water, kept in a plastic bag kept over the top of ice in a container
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Finger washed with water, kept in a plastic bag kept over the top of ice in a container Bag in Bag technique: If it is anticipated that the amputated part will be considered for replantation, it is critical to transport the patient and the part in an appropriate manner. The amputated part is placed in a clean, dry, plastic bag, which is sealed and placed on top of ice in a styrofoam container. This keeps the part sufficiently cool at 4° C to 10° C without freezing. The amputated part is wrapped in lightly moistened saline gauze to prevent tissue drying.

Highyeild:

In the "Bag in Bag" technique, the amputated finger is washed with clean water to remove any dirt or debris. It is then placed in a clean, dry, plastic bag, which is sealed to prevent contamination. The bag is then placed on top of ice in a Styrofoam container. The ice should not come into direct contact with the amputated part, as this can cause tissue damage. The Styrofoam container provides insulation to maintain a temperature of 4° C to 10° C, which is the optimal range for preserving the amputated part without freezing.

Extraedge:

To prevent tissue drying, the amputated part is wrapped in lightly moistened saline gauze. This helps to keep the tissues hydrated. The time between amputation and replantation is critical and can significantly affect the success of the procedure.

questions.text: The following is/are true about super microsurgery:

options.label: A
options.text: Perforator to Perforator anastomoses can make reconstruction accurate

options.label: B
options.text: It begins to make the previously constrained donor sites and recipient’s vessels redundant

options.label: C
options.text: It has also been used in the lymphatico-venous anastomosis

questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Super microsurgery: In the last decade, Koshima’s description of anastomosing vessels with a diameter of 0.8mm or less has been utilized to improve perforator flap donor site morbidity, as well as the speed of flap harvest. So-called ‘ perforator to perforator ’ anastomoses can make reconstruction very accurate in skilled hands. It begins to make the previously constrained selection of flap donor sites and recipient’s vessels redundant, with terms such as ‘ freestyle free flap ’ being coined to describe such versatility in reconstructive work. The technique has also been used to advance the art of lymphatico-venous anastomosis to treat lymphoedema . Incorrectly selected cases and with good facilities, such surgery has begun to offer new therapeutic options to those with chronically morbid conditions.

Highyeild:

Supermicrosurgery involves micro neurovascular anastomosis of vessels and the coaptation of single nerve fascicles. This technique allows for the reconstruction of fingertip injuries that would have previously required amputation.

Extraedge:

Supermicrosurgery has expanded the field of microsurgery even further. The vessels and nerve fascicles involved are typically 0.3-0.8 mm in size.

questions.text: The most common fluid used in Burns resuscitation is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hartmann's solution The resuscitation volume is relatively constant in proportion to the area of the body burned and, therefore, there are formulae that calculate the approximate volume of fluid needed for the resuscitation of a patient of a given body weight with a given percentage of the body burned. These regimes follow the fluid loss, which is at its maximum in the first 8 hours and slows, such that, by 24–36 hours, the patient can be maintained his or her normal daily requirements. There are three types of fluid The most common is Ringer’s lactate or Hartmann’s solution ; some centers use human albumin solution or fresh-frozen plasma ; and some centers use hypertonic saline .

Highyeild:

Resuscitation fluid should commence from the time of burn injury and any delay must be caught up. Intravenous resuscitation is appropriate for adults with burns greater than 15% TBSA and children with burns greater than 10% TBSA . Depending on the resources available, some countries commence intravenous fluid resuscitation at 30% TBSA . Oral resuscitation may be necessary, but additional salt solutions are required to avoid fatal hyponatremia and water intoxication . Three variables affect fluid requirements : percentage of TBSA burned, patient weight, and rate/type of fluid. Three main fluids are used in resuscitation: crystalloid (most common), colloid , and hypertonic saline , each with advantages and disadvantages.

Extraedge:

The modified Parkland formula is widely used for fluid resuscitation in burns TBSA% burn weight (kg) × 4 = volume in mL The formula is administered over 24 hours, with the first half given in 8 hours and the second over 16 hours. In children, maintenance fluid (dextrose-saline) should also be given, with varying doses based on body weight. Crystalloid resuscitation may lead to increased tissue edema due to its requirement for eight-fold greater volumes compared to colloid.
